conversations.content: What are you up to, Meene?
Eating berries and brushing my wings. Would you like some, Zethia?
Oh, um, thank you. Er, but if I might ask you a strange question...?
By all means.
Do all faeries enjoy berries?
Not that I am aware of. Why do you ask?
Well, I have another faerie friend who loves them, so I was simply curious.
You don't say! Well then, you must be quite used to faeries by now.
Sadly, she doesn't remember anything of her childhood or the Faerie Kingdom.
So you are actually teaching me much when it comes to your ways.
There are few faeries in the human world. To face that and suffer from amnesia must have been a struggle indeed.
I don't doubt it, but she always had a cheery smile. She is my dearest friend.
Heh. I'm certain you were the cause of many of those smiles.
...There, that should keep my wings in order for now. Spick-and-span and not a scale out of place!
They're beautiful. I love how they sparkle.
Well, aren't you sweet! Wings are terribly important to my kind, you know.
They serve as proof of what we are— we can't even enter the Faerie Kingdom without them.
Truly?!
True and truer still. We spoke before about how we faeries hit a temporary growth spurt when we reach maturity, yes?
Normally, we return to the way we were with time, but if our wings are broken, we lose the ability to change size.
Meaning you can't become small again?
That's right. And sadly, only small faeries are permitted to live in the kingdom.
Losing our wings effectively makes a faerie an exile, so you can see why we all hold them so dear.
Still, there are some who choose to part with their wings willingly.
But...why?
Usually it involves a faerie who leaves the kingdom and falls in love with a human or that sort of thing.
I suppose whatever they found outside is worth casting home and family aside.
I would never have such courage...
And what of faeries who enter the human world while their bodies are yet small?
Hmm... I don't think I've ever heard of one. Why do you ask this?
...Because my friend did so.
Amnesia AND a small body? My word...
Whoever this faerie is, she's clearly quite the exceptional case.
Faeries are sticklers for tradition by nature, and we simply ADORE our little rules. To break with them like that is...
Oh, Notte...
Oh, listen to me. I've worried you. Come here, you poor dear.
Hmm?
There, there! *huuuug*
Eh?! Er, Meene...?!
I'm sorry. Have I upset you?
No, not upset! It was just a bit... Well, embarrassing, perhaps.
Hee hee! Well, it certainly took the gloomy expression from your face. I used to do that for Ilia all the time, you know?
Sadly, she doesn't permit me such pleasures now that she's grown.
So you decided to raise her even knowing you would have to part eventually?
How did you arrive at such a decision?
I suppose it was the first time I found a meaning to my life. I felt...needed.
How so, exactly?
Ah, now THERE is a story! Sit down and get comfortable, dear, and I will tell you all about the night I first met Ilia...
I will never forget the night I first left the Faerie Kingdom.
I was so skittish, I took a couple of steps into the surrounding forest and...stopped.
Sixteen years earlier...
*sniff* Well, great. Now I've dallied so long that night has fallen.
(It would be dangerous to set out in search of a town now, so perhaps it's best to find a safe spot to bed down for the evening.)
EEEK!
Oh, it's just a bunny... Your cottony tush nearly gave me heart failure, Mr. Bunny!
(Oh, but I hate this. Why DO we have this stupid tradition of going out into the human world, anyway?)
(I can't do this; I lack both the bravery and talent of my siblings.)
(I'm just the timid baby of the family, and I'm going to end the night in some forest critter's stomach!)
I've barely ever left the palace, let alone the kingdom. It's hopeless!
EEEAGH! Wh-what is THAT?!
Waaah! Waaaah!
Is that a baby? But why would...?
Waaah!
(Why is there a baby crying in the woods at night?)
(I'm frightened...but also worried.)
Eeep!
He...lp...
Wh-what happened? Oh, you're hurt!
The child... Take...my Ilia...
Then the baby I heard is your daughter? Who has done this thing to you?!
She's not breathing... No! This can't be happening!
Didja find 'er?!
Not yet, but I know she's in these woods!
(Are those men chasing her?)
WAAAH! WAAAAH!
Oy! I 'ear a baby!
They're coming this way!
I've got to get out of here!
That light... Is it dawn already?
(It seems her foul pursuers have given up the chase.)
I guess they didn't expect a baby to fly off into the treetops.
Wah?
Oh! I'm sorry, little one! I didn't mean to wake you.
Waaah! WAAAAAAH!
Oh dear. What's wrong? Are you hungry?
What do human babies even eat? Was that woman your mother? Where is your father?
Waaah!
Oh, please do stop crying!
(This child is even weaker than I am; she won't live out the day if I abandon her.)
(I may not be special—and I may be a coward—but I have to get it together.)
Easy there, little Ilia. I've got you.
I traveled from town to town in search of her father, but he never turned up, so—
Er, might we back up a moment? This is rather a lot to process.
If I may, how old ARE you, Meene? You don't seem much older than myself.
Hee hee! That's a secret. But I'll let you know that we faeries live much longer lives than your kind—and look younger.
I suppose so. Now then, did I mishear, or did you say you lived in a palace?
Correct. I am a princess.
Oh! I...I see.
The youngest of thirteen, though. Oh, and we hide our status while out in the world, so it doesn't confer any perks.
That's still rather remarkable.
The whole point of our time in the human realm is to learn more about the world without the benefit of status.
Now, I certainly didn't mean to spend my time there raising a child, but I'm still very glad that I met Ilia.
To be honest, I'd always felt inferior to my older siblings; I was weak, shy, and so terribly afraid of everything.
But raising her changed all that, and I rather like the faerie I've become.
A love that crosses the bounds of race...
Indeed. In these days, humans and dragons are locked in war, and we faeries have taken the side of the dragons.
The origins of our kind lie with them, after all, and we still share a deep bond.
I remember hearing that dragons and faeries were distant relatives.
That's right. So, strictly speaking, faeries and humankind should be enemies.
But my love for Ilia makes all that quite meaningless.
It is unshakable—and it always will be.
...Again?
What's wrong, Ilia?
Meene is always going out lately and she never tells me where.
Is that a problem?
Well, no...but I'm still curious!
She's never really been into secrets and stuff before, you know?
If it weighs on your mind, why not ask her?
Yeah, but what if it's...you know? Delicate. Like a boyfriend or something.
Is THAT a problem?
Look, there's no dang problem! It's just a mother-daughter sort of thing, okay?! It's weird to talk about this stuff with her!
Then I suppose you will need to find out some other way.
Ugh. The more I talk about this, the more it's starting to bug me.
Let's follow her. C'mon, Mordecai!
That's...a dragon!
Yeah, but that one's okay. Now hush up so I can make with the peeping.
But aren't dragons the enemy?
To you and humans, maybe, but Meene's a faerie. Now please! Hush already!
If you say so...
A seat has been readied for you; your father said as much.
A lovely, yet hollow gesture. I'm sure there isn't a single task of import he would entrust to his failed youngest.
While it is fact that your brothers and sisters are talented, I see no cause to denigrate yourself so.
You're right. Here I fancy myself as a changed faerie, but I slip right back into old habits. It's simply terrible.
I wonder if I'll stop being myself if I return?
Are you wavering?
No. Not going back was never an option for me.
Soon, I'll have no choice but to return to the Faerie Kingdom.
...Let's go, Mordecai.
Ilia?
Will Meene really return to the Faerie Kingdom?
No question about it.
Did you know about this?
I never heard it from her in as many words, but I learned enough to see the writing on the wall some time ago.
Apparently faeries of a certain age grow in size for a time.
They use those years to learn about the outside world, then head back home once they're ready to shrink down again.
Once they do, that's that—they never set foot outside their kingdom again.
So once Meene leaves...
Yeah. We won't ever see her again.
Are you okay with that?
If I'm honest, it doesn't feel real. She's been there since... Well, forever.
I can't really imagine what it'd be like if she just...wasn't, you know?
I knew the day would come, but I tried not to think about it and kept putting it off...
And what about now?
Now I finally have to face it—but at least I already know what I need to do.
And what is that?
I've got to grow up—and fast. Enough to be all right on my own.
I can't have Meene worrying about me after she leaves.
A few days later...
Ilia still isn't back. Do you think something might have happened to her?
Why in the world would she travel to the capital now, of all times? Why didn't you stop her, Mordecai?
It was in her own best interest— and in yours, Meene.
What is THAT supposed to mean?
I'm baaack!
And where have you been, young lady?!
Just to the capital and back.
Whyever FOR?!
Negotiating sales of a new invention! I'm working on developing some new distribution routes.
But why NOW? You know the army is busy looking for you.
Was it something you really had to do in the middle of all this danger? Because it sure doesn't sound like it.
No. It had to be now.
Why? What could possibly be more important than your LIFE?
I'm not saying that! I'm just...
No buts, young lady. You have to learn to take proper care of yours—
I'M FINE, OKAY?! You can stop worrying about me all the freaking time!
I'm not a little girl anymore!
Ilia...?
Sorry, I'm... Look, I'm going to bed.
*sigh* It's never easy. Sorry about that.
That's all right. But are YOU well?
Truthfully, I'm a bit shocked. We've never really fought before.
She's right, though: She's a wonderful, mature woman now, and I need to learn to let go of my baby girl.
I'm going to step out for some air. You two go ahead and sleep.
They love each other so much, yet they still manage to hurt one another... Love is a tricky thing indeed.
Letting go is never easy.
There are as many forms of love as there are people, so what do you suppose Meene will choose in the end?
I don't know. But whatever it is, I hope it's a choice neither she nor Ilia will regret.
When I met Ilia, she was all alone— just a tiny, fragile thing.
But in a way, I was as well—and meeting her helped me to learn who I was and grow stronger as a result.
And while she means everything to me, I fear the opposite is no longer true.
She's met her own special someone and found a love across the boundaries of race, just as I did with her.
Knowing that, I should...
I'm going home. Will you tell my father?
I'll take on whatever role he has for me and find a way to be of use.
And what of Ilia?
What of her? It was always a given that we would have to part ways eventually. It's not something either of us can change.
Besides, she's all grown-up. Even normal parents send their children off eventually.
So it's time I grew up as well. I need to let her go.
Ilia's out late again...
She's...she's fine. I'm certain of it. She's a grown woman, after all.
You say that, but I know you are worried almost to the point of illness.
I have to trust her. What kind of mother would I be if I refused to let her go?
You can trust in her and still worry. She's important to you.
Mordecai's right. Take a long, hard look at your feelings and come up with an answer that feels right.
There's no set rule for what you ＂have＂ to do. You and Ilia should find the answer that's right for the two of you.
I'm going out to look for her. What will you do, Meene?
...I'm coming with you.
We'll all go together!
(Damn. I let my guard down because it was a merchant I've dealt with for years.)
(That rat took one look at the bounty on my head and sold me out to the army!)
*huff* *pant*
(I've shaken some of them, but there are still plenty on my tail... This isn't good.)
Ilia! This way!
Guys?!
Hey! That's the thing from the other world!
Grab it along with the alchemist!
Why did you come here?!
Because we were worried about you.
I'll hold them here.
But...
I'll make it back to you. You trust me, yes?
Yes, Mordecai. I trust you.
Let's go! Quickly!
*pant* *heave*
We've been running forever!
I don't think anyone's still following us, thanks to Mordecai. We're probably safe to walk for a—
Ah!
(The ground's giving way!)
ILIA!
Ilia! Meene!
That was a heck of a fall. Sort of a miracle I'm still in one piece.
Thank goodness...
Meene! You broke my fall!
AUGH! YOUR WING IS BENT!
Yes, it happened when I fell.
Don't be so chill about this! What do we DO?!
We wait. It isn't broken, which means it will heal up in time.
But wings are everything to a faerie!
Just let me hold you, child. I'm only glad you're safe.
What?
I don't care about my wings—the only thought in my head was keeping you safe.
You would sacrifice yourself for me after the terrible things I said to you?
I'm your mother, silly. Faerie, human, arguments—none of that matters.
And though the ＂right＂ answer may be elusive, seeing my wings in this condition makes one thing very clear...
You are the most precious thing in the world to me, Ilia, and I love you.
Aw, Mom...
I'm so sorry for all the trouble I've caused. I just wanted to become independent so that you could go back home.
I thought if I did more work and made extra money, you wouldn't have to worry as much about me.
But I only made you worry MORE and then this happened and... Well, I'm sorry.
I need to apologize to you as well; I was still treating you like a child.
I should have been your biggest believer, but instead I pushed my own worries on to you and tried to keep you under my guard.
I'm sorry you got saddled with such a clingy mother.
...We haven't exactly been making things easy on one another, huh?
But you deserve a better daughter, and I know you want to be the best mother you can be, so we've got to get it together.
I got so caught up in what the right thing to do was, I forgot to consider your feelings OR my own! What a fool I was.
...Hey, Mom? Thanks for raising me all these years.
Don't worry about me. Choose whatever is right for you so that you don't regret it.
I believe in you, child, and will support you now and always.
Iliaaa!
Meeeeene!
It's Zethia and Mordecai! Over heeere!
(I thought I'd grown stronger, but I'm still so weak. It seems I was just dependent on Ilia this whole time.)
(I need to become capable of living my life even without her.)
(That is the shape of my love: The right answer for both of us.)
May I ask you a strange question, Zethia?
What is it?
What is it like for a human to be in love?
Er, why do you ask this?
My apologies. I know speaking of romance can be rather awkward for some.
No, it's not that—I'm simply curious why you are asking about humans.
I was struck with a curiosity to learn more about them, I suppose.
I'm sure I've told you that we faeries come to the human world to learn of what life is like outside our kingdom, yes?
Well, I've been so caught up in raising Ilia that I never had time to study anything past keeping a human child in one piece.
I'm afraid that has given me tunnel vision. If I want to be able to offer her support, I need to keep learning.
In the years to come, Ilia will forge relationships with all manner of people, just as she has with you and Mordecai.
I don't want to stand in her way out of ignorance; I want to learn and help her.
You sound like you've made peace with something.
You're the one who told me to face my own feelings and find the right solution for us, and you were absolutely correct.
I'd used tradition and my royal birth as a kind of excuse to avoid thinking about how I really felt.
I never thought for myself because following rules was so much easier.
But I can't do that anymore. I have someone I love dearly now.
Even when it's hard, I need to think for myself. To find my own answers. My own choices that I won't regret.
So I can't decide just yet.
I know full well I could wake up tomorrow faerie sized once more.
And I still can't say what will be the most important thing to me when that happens.
But whatever I choose, I want to know that I won't regret it, which means taking the time to introspect now.
I'm not using rules and traditions as an excuse any longer. I'm going to make up my mind and live with my decisions.
...I see.
You're not upset? I thought you might be.
If anything, I find the sentiment rather commendable.
Come again?
It's true: You were a timorous little thing, following along after your brothers and sisters like a lost pup. But look at you now.
You've grown strong, Meene.
You know what? I did. And small wonder...
Because I became a mom.
